content:
ASIA-PAC

World Health Organization declared the coronavirus is a Public Health Emergency of International Concern in which the decision was near unanimous although does not recommend limiting trade and movement due to the China outbreak and noted the greatest concern is for the virus to spread to countries with weaker health systems. Furthermore, WHO said there has been progress made in developing a vaccine and believes measures taken by China "will reverse the tide", while it opposes any measures or restrictions on travel or trade to China. (Newswires)

China coronavirus cases have reportedly increased to 8,149 (Prev. 7711). (Newswires)

CDC confirmed first human to human transmission of coronavirus in the US to bring total number of cases in US to 6 (Prev. 5), in which the new patient is the spouse of the Chicago woman who brought the infection back from Wuhan. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said he does not see material effect on the economy from the coronavirus and that the US does not see the coronavirus outbreak as a leverage point over China. Furthermore, Kudlow stated relations with China have improved greatly and that the two sides are working closely together on implementing the Phase One agreement. (Newswires)

Fonterra said New Zealand December milk production fell by 0.5% on a litre basis, but rose 0.2% on a milk solids basis, while Australia milk production fell by 3.4% in November on a Y/Y basis. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

  • BoE Bank Rate (Jan) 0.75% vs. Exp. 0.75% (Prev. 0.75%). (Newswires) 
  • BoE QE Gilts (Jan) 435B vs. Exp. 435B (Prev. 435B) 
  • BoE QE Corp (Jan) 10B vs. Exp. 10B (Prev. 10B)

BoE voted 7-2 to hold rates at 0.75% (Exp. 6-3) with Haskel and Saunders voting to cut, while it dropped its reference to ‘limited and gradual’ tightening but noted that “some modest” tightening of monetary policy may be needed further out if the economy recovers as forecast. BoE added that monetary policy may need to reinforce expected growth recovery if recent signs of stronger global and domestic activity are not sustained, while it noted that UK potential growth has weakened due to reduced investment and Brexit. However, it assumes an immediate but orderly move at the beginning of next year, to a deep free trade agreement between UK-EU and suggested that risks to GDP are ‘broadly balanced’ and sees support from government budget.

BoE Governor Carney said UK recovery appears to be on track and indicators of uncertainty have fallen. However, he noted that although global growth is picking up, caution is warranted and that evidence of a pick up in growth is not widespread, while he added that a renewal of trade tensions could reverse progress and coronavirus remains.

BoE Governor Carney stated that UK economy is 'so far good enough' but data needs to fill in or additional stimulus likely to be required' and future policy moves depend on how economy evolves. Furthermore, Carney noted that market pricing shows BoE rate cut leads to inflation outcome above target which is inconsistent with BoE remit and stated that BOE's previous 'limited and gradual' phrasing implied multiple rate rises which is not the case now.

MARKET RECAP

The WHO declared the coronavirus as a PHEIC (Public Health Emergency of International Concern) - decision was near unanimous, although risk appetite ramped up on the tail-end of the WHO press conference, seemingly on the fact that despite the PHEIC declaration, the WHO has said it opposes any travel or trade restrictions to China - participants had feared restrictions would follow the emergency declaration. Therefore, one could anticipate this as a "soft" or "growth/market friendly" outcome. Tesla (TSLA) surged following EPS and revenue beats whilst highlighting its goals, such as increase Model 3 production at its Shanghai facility, increased Model Y production at Fremont, whilst noting Model 3 and Y capacity from Fremont should reach 500k per year after expansion by mid-2020. Facebook (FB) was hit despite slight beats across the board, which some have noted is still disappointing. FB forecasted a continued decline in pace of advertising revenue growth, which was weaker than some of the “whisper” numbers, also hampering the stock. Microsoft (MSFT) traded with solid gains following beats across the board with solid growth in its key Azure cloud unit. Coca Cola (KO) reported revenue beats while providing guidance slightly above analyst expectations. Paypal (PYPL) traded in the red following a weaker than expected guidance for the next quarter, however the majority of losses had pared back throughout the session.  Lam Research (LRCX) hit all-time highs following beats on EPS and revenue, whilst providing strong guidance for Q3. ServiceNow (NOW) benefitted after top and bottom line beats and reporting a 35% increase in subscription revenue. UPS (UPS) traded lower after providing disappointing guidance, which weighed on competitor FDX. SPX +0.32% at 3284, NDX +0.26% at 9299, DJI +0.43% at 28,859.

The T-PLEX was firmer across the curve on Thursday, albeit off its highs into the settlement. Risk appetite was subdued throughout most of the session amid growing the growing coronavirus cases/deaths and mixed US Q4 GDP, although the WHO reversed sentiment after providing a "soft" emergency declaration, advising against trade and travel restrictions. By settlement, yields were approximately 3bps lower across the curve. US T-note (H0) settled 9+ ticks higher at 131-10.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 30th January 2020: Risk assets bid amid ‘soft’ WHO emergency declaration, BoE stands pat
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW WHO declare coronavirus as global emergency, although oppose limiting trade and travel to China; BoE stands pat, 7-2 vote split, removes guidance on gradual limited hikes, GDP beat, internals weak.
  • COMING UP: Data & Events: US PCE, Chicago PMI, UoM Survey (Final); EZ CPI & GDP (Flash); Baker Hughes US Rig Count; UK GfK Consumer Confidence. Earnings: XOM, CVX, HON, CHTR, CAT, CL

* CORONAVIRUS: The WHO declared the coronavirus as a PHEIC (Public Health Emergency of International Concern) - decision was near unanimous. However, Risk appetite ramped up on the tail-end of the WHO press conference, seemingly on the fact that despite the PHEIC declaration, the WHO has said it opposes any travel or trade restrictions to China - participants had feared restrictions would follow the emergency declaration. Therefore, one could anticipate this as a "soft" or "growth/market friendly" outcome. Furthermore, the WHO stressed that it believed China had taken adequate measures to "reverse the tide". Prior to the decision the US CDC confirmed the first human to human transmission of coronavirus in the US, which took the number of confirmed cases to 6 from 5. The new patient is the spouse of the Chicago woman who brought the infection back from Wuhan. Meanwhile the number of cases in China picked up to 8149 from 7711, and total deaths now at 170, while suspected cases are said to have increased to over 12k. The total number of coronavirus cases exceed 8100 worldwide; surpassing the number of SARS cases seen in 2003.

* BOE: Heading into this week’s policy announcement, markets were on a “knife-edge” over what to expect from the MPC, with a roughly 50:50 chance assigned to a rate cut vs. hold decision. The uncertainty emanated partially from a slew of dovish interjections from Governor Carney, Tenreyro and Vlieghe; none of which were the in the “cut” camp in December. Furthermore, tier 1 data releases including GDP, retail sales and CPI also led some to call for a rate reduction ahead of the meeting, albeit some of these calls were pared back following more upbeat and timelier indicators including the Markit PMI report. In the end, the MPC opted to stand pat on rates in what was a 7-2 vote vs. analyst consensus of a 6-3 split in views; a decision which saw an unwinding of some of the dovish bets placed in the market. Focus for the accompanying minutes from the meeting was placed on the Bank’s decision to drop its reference to “limited and gradual” rate rises and instead guide towards the possibility of “some modest” tightening of monetary policy further out if the economy recovers as forecast; something the Governor later clarified as implying that multiple rate rises in the future is no longer the case; ING noted that “while the debate on tightening is clearly some way off, this may nevertheless be taken as mildly hawkish by some in the market”. Furthermore, from a stimulus perspective, policymakers reiterated their willingness to act by stating that monetary policy “may need to reinforce expected growth recovery, if recent signs of stronger global and domestic activity are not sustained”. This will make upcoming data increasingly important as markets look to gauge the extent of the post-election “bounce”. Note, the lack of MPC members switching to the “cut” camp could imply that the BoE views activity as picking up at the start of the year; during the press conference, Carney suggested that the UK recovery appears to be on track, albeit, UK growth and inflation are not yet “assured”. This is something that was reflected by the MPR projections which saw noteworthy reductions to 2020, 2021 and 2022 growth prospects, whilst inflation forecasts were raised in the near term but lowered further down the curve. That said, Carney downplayed the importance of projections in the November press conference given the uncertainties facing the UK economy. Of note, naturally, one of those largest uncertainties is in the form of Brexit, on which, the MPC continues to assume “an immediate but orderly move, at the beginning of next year, to a deep free trade agreement between the UK and the EU”; in-line with government policy. Overall, ING concludes that policy easing cannot be totally ruled out this year, however, the fact that no policymakers switched to the rate cut camp this week, shows that the MPC is more likely to stand pat on rates in the coming meetings.

* US GDP & PCE ADVANCE (Q4): Headline US GDP growth came in at 2.1% in Q4, in line with the consensus. The core PCE deflator rose 1.3%, missing the consensus 1.7%. Consumer spending rose at a rate of 1.8%, from the prior 3.2%. Oxford Economics argued that the headline gives the illusion of an economy chugging along at a moderate pace, but the breakdown reveals a softer picture: "More than 70% of the Q4 advance in output came from a temporary collapse in imports, while business investment remained subdued and consumers spent more cautiously," the consultancy writes, "the new decade will bring about sub-potential GDP growth around 1.7% as numerous headwinds keep businesses side-lined while households reduce their outlays in line with gently cooling income." In terms of policy implications, the Fed will likely take the report as confirmation that the economy is in a good place and policy is appropriate, but OxEco argues that disappointing growth in early 2020, along with sub-2% inflation, as well as tightening in financial conditions, will lead a dovish Fed to provide additional policy accommodation in mid-2020.

* UK/US TRADE: US Secretary of State Pompeo stated that the US intends to put the UK at the front of the line on trade, adding that he thinks the US-UK relationship is at a fantastic place. Pompeo’s tone is more positive here, despite the UK's decision to accept limited Huawei influence on UK's 5G network, which was thought to strain relations between the two sides; other US officials have warned previously of consequences for the UK if it were to accept Huawei into its 5G infrastructure. Furthermore, in a Fox interview, US Commerce Secretary Ross said there is a reasonable chance that a US-UK trade deal can be achieved prior to a pact with the EU, although he caveated his point by saying that the UK’s Huawei decision was too lenient.

* GERMAN CPI PRELIM (JAN): Headline inflation rose to 1.7% Y/Y from 1.5%, matching the consensus. The harmonised measure rose to 1.6% Y/Y from 1.5%. Pantheon Macroeconomics said the v-shaped recovery in German inflation is complete, but the consultancy doubts that it will unsettle markets or the ECB. January's upside was a result of higher food and energy costs. Pantheon notes that the estimate for the core rate in this report, but making inferences from other data, says it likely fell to 1.4% Y/Y from 1.7%. "If our estimate of the core rate is correct, it is now a bit under our estimate of the trend, at 1.5-to-1.6%," Pantheon says. Elsewhere, it thinks the headline rate will remain elevated through Q1. "Energy inflation tends to lag oil prices a bit in Germany, indicating that it will remain sticky in the next few months even as the Y/Y growth rate in oil prices wane."

* WTI (H0) SETTLED USD 1.19 LOWER AT USD 52.14/BBL; BRENT (H0) SETTLED USD 1.58 LOWER AT USD 57.33/BBL: The energy complex’s decline continued Thursday as the macro narrative shifted back to the ongoing coronavirus. Prices got off on the back-foot overnight amid headlines alluding to the growing number of cases and deaths, where the latest concerns stemmed from the CDC announcing the first human-to-human transfer in the US. Meanwhile, the US Advance Q4 GDP print was strong in the headline, although the details under the hood were less so, and some additional equity pressure on the US cash open dug the heel in for the oil market’s losses, which by settlement, had been offered more severely than equity futures. Meanwhile, OPEC sources suggested that the group had begun discussions on advancing forward the OPEC+ meeting to early February from March due to the price declines, but no final decision has yet been made – the supply side of the oil market has had little bullish impact as of late amid the coronavirus related demand concerns, where the market has OPEC support priced in. Citigroup notes that it has seen two-way flows, where some participants have been continuing to “buy the dip” as they see the weakness in recent weeks as overdone, although the strategy has yet to prove successful. The bank also highlights that book squaring could be at play ahead of March Brent, February heating oil and February RBOB gasoline contract expiry on Friday.

* CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.32% at 3284, NDX +0.26% at 9299, DJI +0.43% at 28,859

* EARNINGS: Tesla (TSLA) surged following EPS and revenue beats whilst highlighting its goals, such as increase Model 3 production at its Shanghai facility, increased Model Y production at Fremont, whilst noting Model 3 and Y capacity from Fremont should reach 500k per year after expansion by mid-2020. Facebook (FB) was hit despite slight beats across the board, which some have noted is still disappointing. FB forecasted a continued decline in pace of advertising revenue growth, which was weaker than some of the “whisper” numbers, also hampering the stock. Microsoft (MSFT) traded with solid gains following beats across the board with solid growth in its key Azure cloud unit. Coca Cola (KO) reported revenue beats while providing guidance slightly above analyst expectations. Paypal (PYPL) traded in the red following a weaker than expected guidance for the next quarter, however the majority of losses had pared back throughout the session.  Lam Research (LRCX) hit all-time highs following beats on EPS and revenue, whilst providing strong guidance for Q3. ServiceNow (NOW) benefitted after top and bottom line beats and reporting a 35% increase in subscription revenue. UPS (UPS) traded lower after providing disappointing guidance, which weighed on competitor FDX.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Carnival (CCL) was hit heavily pre-market on reports a cruise line had been docked with passengers not allowed to leave while they investigated an Asian woman who had fallen ill after traveling to Macau in fear she had the coronavirus – although the woman later tested negative. Southwestern Airlines (LUV) was hit after reports in WSJ stated the airline had flew passengers on jets with unconfirmed maintenance records, where over 17mln passengers had been flown over a two-year period.

* US T-NOTE (H0) SETTLED 9+ TICKS HIGHER AT 131-10: The T-PLEX was firmer across the curve on Thursday, albeit off its highs into the settlement. Risk appetite was subdued throughout most of the session amid growing the growing coronavirus cases/deaths and mixed US Q4 GDP, although the WHO reversed sentiment after providing a "soft" emergency declaration, advising against trade and travel restrictions. By settlement, yields were approximately 3bps lower across the curve

* BOC’S BEAUDRY: Bank of Canada’s Beaudry appears more hawkish than the BOC median, arguing that even if a rate cut seems desirable in the short-term, once growth is factored in the cut may no longer be attractive. Beaudry also highlighted that last October, the BoC could have considered a rate cut to make sure the economy didn't under-perform; but given the state of financial vulnerabilities, it judged the risks of acceleration to house price expectations and debt build-up as too high. Note, in the latest press conference Poloz was cognizant of financial vulnerabilities when considering a rate cut. To conclude, Beaudry highlighted that the main financial vulnerabilities are tied to balance sheets, asset prices and risk allocation.

* FX: GBP an outperformer following the BoE rate decision which was not as dovish at some had anticipated with only Saunders and Haskel dissenting, despite expectations for a 6-3 split. USD lost its ground amid broad GBP strength, however GDP did little to help despite a headline beat as it saw weak internals. CNH remained weaker against the buck as coronavirus cases continue to rise and as the WHO declared the virus as a PHEIC, however they opposed a limit to trade and travel to China. CAD initially traded weaker against the buck however comments from BoC’s Beaudry who suggested even if a rate cut seems desirable in the short term, once growth is factored in, the cut may no longer be attractive. AUD and NZD found no reprieve and continued to lose ground against the dollar, with NZD breaching its 200dma at 0.6510 to eventually cross the round figure in the tail end of trade. Meanwhile, AUD found support within a whisker of 0.67 before regaining traction slightly. JPY and XAU ended the day relatively flat against the greenback, after a bid into the havens on continued coronavirus contagion, before paring back amidst a ‘dovish’ PHEIC declaration on the coronavirus. EMFX was weaker across the board, with the ZAR hampered by reports of further load shedding by state utility Eskom, and RUB on a decline in oil prices.

content:
Q4 Expectations (USD):

  • EPS: 4.04
  • Revenue: 86.02bln (vs. Co guidance of 80.00-86.5bln)
  • GM: 37.77%
  • OM: 3.11%
  • AWS: 9.84bln

  • Subscription Services: 5.16bln
  • Third Party Seller Services: 16.29bln
  • COGS: 53.59bln
  • OPEX: 35.66bln
  • Tax Rate: 18.10%

Q1 ‘20 Expectations (USD):    

  • EPS: 6.07
  • Revenue: 71.65bln

FY20 Expectations (USD):    

  • EPS: 26.07
  • Revenue: 330.98bln

Analyst Ratings: 18 Strong Buys, 30 Buys, 3 Holds, 0 Sells, 0 Strong Sells

Amazon’s share price had a relatively lacklustre 2019, rising 20%, lower than both the NDX (+39%) and SPX (+30%), where it failed to track the wider market post its Q3 ’19 report: Revenue guidance was soft and its cloud unit AWS sales came in below expectations. The consumer sector has remained firm, with November and December US Retail Sales figures not sounding any alarms; furthermore, Cyber Monday and Black Friday have seen record-beating figures again in 2019 and Amazon itself has provided an olive branch to consumers with its shift to free one-day shipping – seeing the street’s Q4 Revenue expectation lie at the top-end of the Co’s Q3 guidance. Meanwhile, the market will be paying close attention to AWS growth in the competitive and grossing cloud sector – note Microsoft’s (MSFT) Azure printed forecast-beating growth in its report on Wednesday and concerns linger on AWS’ dominance in cloud infrastructure.

Analysts on the street generally expect a strong quarterly report despite the shortened holiday calendar, Wedbush’s Pachter (Outperform, USD 2,000 PT) believes if there were to be any weakness, Third Party would likely be the culprit; many cite free one-day shipping as a tailwind, although BMO’s Salmon (“Outperform”, USD 2,150 PT) believes the quarter will mark the peak for the feature. Expectations are a bit more subdued for AWS’ trajectory however, with apprehensions that the unit’s margins could come under pressure. Credit Suisse’s Ju (“Outperform”, USD 2,100 PT) notes that AWS is poised to aggressively pursue larger enterprise clients, but its operating margin will likely compress before heading higher, in addition to the likely entering of a period of structurally lower margins. Going into the report, Wells Fargo’s Fitzgerald (“Overweight”, USD 2,300 PT) believes expectations may be somewhat muted for the quarter and the Q1 guide, seeing slightly faster AWS growth.

subject: BoC'c Beaudry says even if a rate cut seems desirable in the short-term, once the Bank has factored in growth risk, the cut may no longer be attractive
content:
• Even if macroprudential policy is best suited to ensure the resilience of the financial system, it doesn't mean it is capable in eliminating all risks associated with financial vulnerability
  • This is not a departure form our inflation-targeting objective but rather another tool to judge risks to the inflation outlook
  • The main financial vulnerabilities are tied to balance sheets, asset prices and risk allocation
  • Last October, the Bank could have considered a rate cut to make sure the economy didn't under-perform;, but given the state of financial vulnerabilites, Bank judged the risks of acceleration of house price expectations and debt buildup as too high acceleration

reaction_details: • As the pres conference began ramping up and the WHO had expressed its confidence on the containment of the coronavirus, ES March '20 futures rose from 3256 to 3270 over the space of 10 minutes, WTI (H0) futures rose from 52.30 to 52.75, T-Note (H0) futures fell from 131-16 to lows of 131-07.
analysis_details: • Risk appetite has ramped up on the tail-end of the WHO press conference, seemingly on the fact that despite the PHEIC declaration, the WHO has said it opposes any travel or trade restrictions to China - participants had feared restrictions would follow the emergency declaration. Therefore, one could anticipate this as a "soft" or "growth/market friendly" outcome. Furthermore, the WHO stressed that it believed China had taken adequate measures to "reverse the tide".

subject: WTI (H0) settled USD 1.19 lower at USD 52.14/bbl; Brent (J0) settles USD 1.58 lower at USD 57.33/bbl
analysis_details: • The energy complex’s decline continued Thursday as the macro narrative shifted back to the ongoing coronavirus. Prices got off on the back-foot overnight amid headlines alluding to the growing number of cases and deaths, where the latest concerns stemmed from the CDC announcing the first human-to-human transfer in the US. Meanwhile, the US Advance Q4 GDP print was strong in the headline, although the details under the hood were less so, and some additional equity pressure on the US cash open dug the heel in for the oil market’s losses, which by settlement, had been offered more severely than equity futures. Meanwhile, OPEC sources suggested that the group had begun discussions on advancing forward the OPEC+ meeting to early February from March due to the price declines, but no final decision has yet been made – the supply side of the oil market has had little bullish impact as of late amid the coronavirus related demand concerns, where the market has OPEC support priced in. Citigroup notes that it has seen two-way flows, where some participants have been continuing to “buy the dip” as they see the weakness in recent weeks as overdone, although the strategy has yet to prove successful. The bank also highlights that book squaring could be at play ahead of March Brent, February heating oil and February RBOB gasoline contract expiry on Friday.

Daily FX Wrap: Sterling receives rate reprieve, but no respite for Aussie or Kiwi
content:
GBP

Almost akin to a game of 2 halves for the Pound that was flogged ahead of the early am fix, mainly via the Eur/Gbp cross for month end purposes, before roaring back in the run up to the BoE and then extending recovery gains when the UK MPC maintained rates with no further dovish dissent. To recap, the January meeting was widely deemed to be ‘live’ given easing prospects boosted by a string of comments leaning towards the 2 existing 25 bp cut advocates, but Governor Carney, Tenreyro and Vlieghe all opted to remain within the on hold fold, leaving Saunders and Haskel in the minority again. Cable hit fresh highs just shy of 1.3100 and briefly breached the big figure as the press conference and Q&A underscored reasons for refraining from policy action and retaining the option to tighten if necessary even though official guidance for gradual hikes was removed, while Eur/Gbp reversed further within a circa 0.8487-13 range.

CHF/EUR/JPY/USD

Notwithstanding some waning of broad risk aversion from extremes prompted by the latest and increasingly worrying Chinese coronavirus updates, the usual beneficiaries during safety flights are still in demand, as Usd/Chf pivots 0.9700, Eur/Chf straddles 1.0700 and Eur/Usd holds above 1.1000, albeit against the backdrop of a generally softer Dollar post-FOMC and above forecast German data (preliminary headline inflation and unemployment over conflicting Eurozone sentiment indices. However, the single currency was capped ahead of decent option expiry interest between 1.1045-50 (1.1 bn), while Usd/Jpy tested stops at 108.75, but did not filled solid bids layered from 108.80 to 108.70. Next up for the Yen, CPI, IP and Retail Sales that could be more influential than US Q4 GDP and initial claims that were too close to median expectations in headline terms to move the DXY out of its tight 97.845-98.077 corridor.

CAD/NZD/AUD/NOK/SEK

The major laggards all day, or for the bulk of Thursday’s (Asia-Pac/EU) trading session as the Loonie extended losses through 1.3200 and nearly touched the 200 DMA (1.3229) amidst even cheaper oil, the Kiwi lost grip of 0.6500 having breached its 200 DMA (0.6510) and got to within a whisker of the next chart support (50% Fib retracement at 0.6480) and the Aussie tested 0.6700 alongside the offshore Yuan swooning to 7.0000 again. Elsewhere, the Scandi Crowns also considerably on a combination of bearish technical, negative fundamentals (like much worse than anticipated Norwegian retail sales) and overall risk-off flows ahead of month end.

EM 

Widespread depreciation vs the Dollar, but notable underperformance in the Rand through 14.8000 on the back of more power problems for SA’s Eskom.

subject: US equities open in negative territory with Facebook (FB) falling 7%, although Tesla (TSLA) +9% to a record high after earnings last night, Microsoft (MSFT) also trading higher
content:
Individual Stock Movers

Winners

  • Tesla (TSLA) +9% following EPS and revenue beats whilst highlighting its goals: Increase Model 3 production at its shanghai facility, Increase Model Y production at Fremont whilst noting Model 3 and Y capacity from Fremont should reach 500k per year after expansion by mid 2020.
  • ServiceNow (NOW) +7% on top and bottom line beats and reporting a 35% increase in subscription revenue
  • Lam Research (LRCX) +5.8% after it reported beats on EPS and revenue, whilst providing strong guidance for Q3

Losers

  • Facebook (FB) -7% despite slight beats across the board, which some have noted as disappointing, whilst also forecasting a continued decline in pace of advertising revenue growth, which was weaker than some of the “whisper” numbers
  • UPS (UPS) -6.5% after providing disappointing guidance, also weighing on FDX
  • Carnival (CCL) -5% on reports of a cruise ship being held to check for Coronavirus, however the latest reports state the tests exclude coronavirus has been excluded from the ship, and thus the losses have reversed, although shares are still 2% lower.
analysis_details: US equities initially opened lower however since losses have pared somewhat with NDX and DJ only slightly lower. NDX and DJI are outperforming the SPX with NDX benefitting from a surge in TSLA and MSFT share prices, which hold a 1.14% and 10% weighting in the index, respectively (MSFT hold a 4% weighting in DJIA). TSLA rallying after EPS and revenue beats and positive rhetoric regarding production and MSFT firmer on beats across the board. However, the losses in Facebook (FB), 4.5% weighting, are weighing after reporting slight beats across the board, although its advertising revenue growth was weaker than some of the whisper numbers, disappointing investors. FB also forecasted a continued decline in the pace of advertising revenue growth. The gains in MSFT are leading to outperformance in the Tech. sector, whilst Consumer Staples also performs well following strong figures from Mondelez (MDLZ), Hershey (HSY) and Archer Daniels Midland (ADM). Communication Services the laggard following Facebook’s (FB) figures, Materials also heavily in the red following a downgrade for Dow (DOW) from RBC, whilst poor earnings from International Paper (IP) and WestRock (WRK) are also weighing.

subject: BOE GOVERNOR CARNEY’S REMARKS AT POST-DECISION PRESSER [ROLLING HEADLINE]
content:
UK ECONOMY

  • UK recovery appears to be on track; indicators of uncertainty have fallen
  • Although signs are encouraging, recovery in UK growth and inflation is not yet assured
  • Labour market remains resilient; there is not much scope for UK labour force participation to rise
  • Survey data suggest actvity has picked up "sharply" since the election, surveys suggests growth will pick up
  • Business reported a sharp rise in investment intentions
  • Lower uncertainty is also boosting housing activity, labour market remains resilient
  • It is early days, less a case of 'so far so good' than 'so far, good enough'
  • UK economy is 'so far good enough', data needs to fill in or additional stimulus likely to be required'; future policy moves depend on how economy evolves

MPC

  • The question for the MPC is whether 2020 is beginning 'with a bang'

FORWARD GUIDANCE

  • Forward guidance is part of the armoury of every major central banks; it is particularly relevant when equilibrium rates are low, or at turning points
  • Market pricing shows BOE rate cut leads to inflation outcome above target, inconsistent with BOE remit
  • 'limited and gradual' phrasing implied multiple rate rises, that is not that case now

DATA

  • Expectations components of surveys has tended not to be reliable, and they do over-predict changes in growth

BREXIT  

  • New trade agreement with the EU will bring 'adjustment costs' for the UK

FORECASTS

  • UK productivity forecasts assume that financial institutions will lose their EU passporting rights in 2021, and that UK banks are given an equivalence designation from the EU

GLOBAL GROWTH  

  • Global growth is picking up, caution is warranted
  • Evidence of a pick-up in growth is not wide spread
  • Renewal of trade tensions could reverse progress, and coronavirus remains
  • Very early to judge the economic impact of coronavirus

subject: UK MARKET UPDATE: BoE holds fire, but tweaks hawkish guidance
content: As widely anticipated given the jury split on a cut or no cut, Gilts, Short Sterling contracts and the Pound have all seen significant price action in wake of the unchanged verdict and no shift in the vote split that is perhaps more surprising given dovish MPC commentary beyond the 2 resident dissenters. The 10 year bond dumped to 134.78 and below yesterday’s 134.89 close, 3 month futures reversed by at least 10 ticks and Cable extended recovery gains over 1.3000 to nigh on 1.3089. Attention now switches to Governor Carney’s farewell post-meeting presser.

  • European bourses are subdued as risk-off resumes on growing virus concerns
  • World Health Organization said evidence of human-to-human transmission outside of China is deeply concerning
  • Japanese medical expert said it has been confirmed in China that the coronavirus can be transmitted from people without symptoms
  • Ahead of BoE market expectations price in around a 50% chance of a cut vs. analyst consensus of 6-3 unchanged
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German CPI (Prelim), US GDP (Advance), Japanese CPI, Unemployment Rate & Retail Sales, BoE Rate Decision, MRP & Press Conference
  • Earnings: Amazon, Visa, Verizon, Coca-Cola, UPS, Altria, Eli Lilly, Raytheon

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China reported there are now 7711 total coronavirus cases and death toll at 170, while suspected cases are said to have increased to 12126. (Newswires) Note, the virus is now in every region of mainland China.

World Health Organization said evidence of human-to-human transmission outside of China is deeply concerning and suggested the numbers outside of China hold the potential for much larger outbreak, while it is to hold an emergency meeting today to re-evaluate whether the outbreak constitutes a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. (Newswires)

Japanese medical expert said it has been confirmed in China that the coronavirus can be transmitted from people without symptoms, while there were separate reports that 3 Japanese nationals who returned from Wuhan yesterday have tested positive for the coronavirus. (Newswires)

White House created a task force on coronavirus in which its members have been meeting daily since Monday, while US President Trump has charged the task force with leading the US government response to the coronavirus. (Newswires) White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said airlines are placing voluntary restrictions on flights to China due to virus outbreak and further restrictions are being discussed. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian sentiment was downbeat as the overhang from the coronavirus outbreak continued to take its toll across the region and following an indecisive lead from the US, where markets reacted to the FOMC policy announcement. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.7%) were subdued with underperformance across Australian mining names as demand concerns overshadowed the higher quarterly production updates by Fortescue Metals and Newcrest Mining, but with downside for the broader market stemmed by resilience in financials, while losses in Tokyo were exacerbated by flows into the JPY. KOSPI (-1.7%) was pressured after index heavyweight Samsung Electronics posted a 38% drop in Q4 net and Hang Seng (-2.6%) slipped deeper into correction territory after the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the mainland increased to 7711 and the death toll now at 170, while the TAIEX (-5.8%) slumped as Taiwan participants returned to the market for the 1st time in 10 days and took their turn to play catch up to the epidemic fears. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher due to the broad weakness in risk appetite and following upside in T-notes which were supported post-FOMC and saw the US 10yr yield decline to a 3-month low, while the mostly improved results from the 2yr JGB auction added fuel to the upside momentum.

US 

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the Fed has been moving in the right direction, but would like them to be bolder, while he also suggested that intensity of EU trade discussions will resume soon. (Fox Business News)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson will inform the EU he is prepared to accept post-Brexit border checks instead of Britain being under EU rules which could mean additional paperwork and physical inspections of goods for businesses. (Telegraph)

EU seeks to create a single European data market to challenge dominance of US tech giants, while large online platforms may face new rules to ensure open and fair competition according to an EU document. (Newswires)

UK Lloyds Business Barometer (Jan) 23 (Prev. 10). (Newswires)

German Saxony State CPI YY (Jan) 1.8% (Prev. 1.4%); MM (Jan) -0.6% (Prev. 0.6%)

German Unemployment Chg SA (Jan) -2k vs. Exp. 5.0k (Prev. 8.0k); Unemployment Rate SA (Jan) 5.0% vs. Exp. 5.0% (Prev. 5.0%)

EU Consumer Confidence Final (Jan) -8.1 vs. Exp. -8.1 (Prev. -8.1), Unemployment Rate (Dec) 7.4% vs. Exp. 7.5% (Prev. 7.5%)

-        Economic Sentiment (Jan) 102.8 vs. Exp. 101.8 (Prev. 101.5, Rev. 101.3)

-        Services Sentiment (Jan) 11.0 vs. Exp. 11.2 (Prev. 11.4, Rev. 11.3)

EQUITIES

An overall bleak session in the European equity-space [Eurostoxx 50 -0.9%] following on from a similar APAC handover which saw the Hang Seng post losses in excess of 2.5% - as risk aversion continues to materialise with the virus outbreak. Sectors are mostly in the red with the exception of utilities amid and outperformance/less pronounced downside in defensives to reflect the risk aversion. The energy sector stands as the underperformer amid the price action in the oil complex coupled with downbeat earnings from oil-titan Shell (-3.4%) which account for ~1.2% of the Stoxx600 and ~10% of the FTSE 100 (Shell A and B shares combined). In terms of earning-driven movers: Roche (+0.7%) remain supported by an above-forecast EPS and a dividend increase despite missing on profit and sales forecasts. Swatch (-3.6%) missed on earnings estimates and noted that it sees no quick rebound in its key Hong Kong market. As such, luxury peers are pressured in sympathy with the likes of LVMH (-1.7%), Richemont (-1.7%) posting firm losses. H&M (+9.8%) rose to the top of pan-European index amid stellar numbers and the appointment of a new CEO. Meanwhile, Deutsche Bank (+2.1%) erased opening losses which came amid a deeper than forecast net loss. Losses diminished amidst the conference call which provided investors with reassurance regarding early signs of progress in its overhaul. Other earnings-related movers include Diageo (-1.9%), Volvo (+7.7%), BT (-5.9%) and Unilever (+1.4%).

Microsoft Corp (MSFT) – Q4 19 EPS USD 1.51 vs. Exp. USD 1.32, Revenue USD 36.9bln vs. Exp. USD 35.68bln - Azure number coming in significantly above street expectations at 64% constant currency growth rate. Intelligent Cloud: USD 11.9bln vs. Exp. 11.40bln vs. Co guidance of USD 11.25bln-11.45bln. Productivity & Business Processes: USD 11.8bln vs. Exp. USD 11.42bln, vs. Co guidance of USD 11.3bln-11.5bln) (Newswires) Co. shares rose 4% after-market

Facebook Inc (FB) - Q4 19 EPS USD 2.56 vs. Exp. USD 2.53, Revenue USD 21.08bln vs. Exp. 20.88bln. MAU 2.5bln (exp. 2.493bln. Ad revenue USD 20.7bln vs. Exp. USD 20.517bln. Boosts buyback programme by USD 10bln. Expenses USD 46.71bln, +51% YY. (Newswires) Co. shares fell 7% after-market

Tesla Inc (TSLA) - Q4 19 Basic EPS USD 2.14 vs. Exp. USD 1.72, Revenue USD 7.38bln vs. Exp. USD 7.02bln; GM 22.5% vs. Prev. 24.3%. Goal is to increase Model 3 capacity further using the Shanghai factory.  (Newsiwres) Co. shares rose 11.6% after-market

FX

USD - Not much bang for the Buck from the Fed as downgrades to the state of US consumption and level of inflation relative to target halted the DXY’s steady rise above 98.000 and sapped broad demand for the Dollar amidst the progressive spread of China’s coronavirus. However, as the death toll and number of cases (confirmed or suspected) continue to mount, Usd/CNH has rebounded further to temporarily test and breach the psychological 7.0000 mark alongside more pronounced depreciation in EM currencies overall, and especially those closely connected or correlated to commodities that are prone to steep price declines on the probability of depressed demand. Hence, the Greenback may well retain a relatively firm underlying bid ahead of data in the form of advance Q4 GDP and initial claims even though a French bank is flagging mild month end selling for portfolio rebalancing purposes.

CHF/EUR/JPY/XAU - The renowned, but not always reliable or consistent safe and pseudo safe havens are all outperforming, and particularly the Franc that has been flagging of late. Usd/Chf has retreated towards 0.9700 and Eur/Chf is back below 1.0700 as the single currency remains heavy on the 1.1000 handle within a spread of hefty Eur/Usd option expiries stretching from 1.0985 (1.3 bn) through 1.1000-05 (1.7 bn) to 1.1045-50 (1.1 bn). Note, firmer German state CPIs, solid jobs data and rather mixed Eurozone sentiment indicators have all hardly impacted, but the Euro did get a boost from more month end cross buying vs the Pound at one stage (into 9 am fix as usual). Meanwhile, the Yen has bounced over 109.00 ahead of a raft of Japanese macro releases and Gold remains bid between Usd1575-82/oz parameters.

NOK/NZD/AUD/CAD/GBP - A triple blow for the Norwegian Krona as a steeper retracement in crude prices against the backdrop of heightened risk aversion combines with a big retail sales miss to propel Eur/Nok beyond resistance around 10.1200 and close to 10.1500. Similarly, the Kiwi, Aussie and Loonie have all declined through deeper chart support and/or significant levels vs their US counterpart, at 0.6500, 0.6737-25 and 1.3200 respectively, with the latter now eyeing Canadian average earnings for some independent impetus. Conversely, Sterling has staged a stoic recovery to reclaim 1.3000+ status in Cable terms and pare some lost ground vs the Euro within a 0.8454-87 band on short covering and position/hedge tweaking ahead of the BoE at high noon as expectations for a 25 bp rate cut or no move flit either side of evens – check out our full preview of super Thursday via the Research Suite.

EM - More pain for regional currencies, but added angst for the Lira as the CBRT Governor echoes Turkey’s Finance Minister with regard to deeming the Try competitive at current levels (circa 5.9800), while maintaining projections for CPI to decelerate further and hit target over the forecast horizon.

CBRT Governor says 2020 year-end inflation forecast mid-point 8.2% (Prev. 8.2%), 2021 mid-point at 5.4%, inflation is expected to stabilise around 5% target in the mid-term, downward trend in inflation expected to continue throughout 2021; Current dollarisation at 51% vs. 56% in May 2019, downward trend seen continuing. CBRT maintains their prudential stance. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.0985 (1.3BLN), 1.1000-05 (1.7BLN), 1.1035-40 (800M), 1.1045-50 (1.1BLN) 

FIXED

It remains to be seen if the dip in debt futures proves transitory or more terminal, and the looming UK rate decision could be crucial if not the determining factor in that regard. Bunds are holding around 174.42, Gilts some ¼ point down from their high (poignantly perhaps given the tight call for -25 bp or nothing from the MPC) and 10 year T-notes just shy of the 131-12 overnight best, while Italian BTPs have recovered from a degree of auction-related selling within 147.41-147.87 confines. Ahead, aside from super Thursday, the first look at US Q4 GDP, weekly claims, a BoC speaker and a slew of Japanese data.

COMMODITIES

Another downbeat session or the energy complex thus far, with prices weighed on by on the ongoing demand implication of the coronavirus, rise in US crude stocks as per yesterday’s DoEs and with the current sentiment also providing further pressure on the contracts. WTI Mar’20 futures found an overnight base at around 52.30/bbl ahead of the Monday’s (and January) low at 52.20/bbl, whilst its Brent counterpart hovers around the 59/bbl at time of writing, with support seen at 58.50/bbl – which marks the January low and has been tested twice this week. On the OPEC -front, the Algerian Energy Minister alluded to the possibility that the March confab will be brought forward to February amid the effect of the Wuhan flu on outbreak on prices, and added that an extension to the output cut pact is possible – no dates have been flagged for a February meeting yet. Moreover, OPEC members are said to be preparing a report on the virus’ impact on energy prices for members to review. Elsewhere, spot gold prices retain an underlying bid, part-aided by the FOMC’s decision yesterday ahead of today’s BOE and WHO presser. Copper prices sees continued downside pressure amid the ongoing coronavirus woes – on a sentiment and demand front with the latter a function of border closures to China.

World Gold Council noted annual gold demand fell 1% Y/Y in 2019 to 4355.7 tons, while it expects India 2020 gold demand to rebound this year from a 3yr low in which it sees India gold demand at 700-800 tons vs. Prev. 690.4 tons last year but will remain below the 10yr average of 843 tons. (Newswires)

subject: Newsquawk Central Banks - PREVIEW: Bank of England Monetary Policy Decision, Minutes and Monetary Policy Report at 1200GMT/0700ET on Thursday 30th January 2020; Carney press conference at 1230GMT/0730ET
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

Following the December policy announcement, where rates were left unchanged at 0.75% along with two dovish dissents, the January meeting has been perceived as increasingly “live” given recent data points and dovish interjections by various MPC members. Consensus for the release looks for rates to be left unchanged at 0.75% with a 6-3 vote split as analysts suggest that, on balance, signs of the UK economy turning a corner and upcoming fiscal support should be enough to convince policymakers to keep their powder dry this time around.

subject: Major FX option expiries for today's NY cut
Gilts and Short Sterling braced for a super BoE (rate cut) Thursday
content: UK debt and STIR contracts have returned to Liffe with a bang on multiple supportive factors, including another marked deterioration in overall risk sentiment due to China’s novel virus, a post-Fed rally and resumption of bull-flattening and front-running the MPC amidst a flip towards easing per market pricing. Meanwhile, the Pound is broadly weakening partly on the shift in rate cut prospects to 50%-plus from just above evens and also due to more Eur/Gbp cross positioning for month end. Looking at price action in depth, Gilts gapped up to 135.31 immediately and extended gains to 63 ticks at a fresh 135.52 contract high before waning alongside Bunds in wake of a tentative bounce in EU equities and firm y/y inflation from the German state of Saxony, while the 3 month strip is just off best levels between 2-4 ticks above parity.

subject: Bunds: nudging new highs for January/2020 on the eve of month end
content: The 10 year German benchmark has now turned full circle from weekly lows to post a fresh peak for the month and ytd at 174.57 on renewed angst over the ongoing spread of China’s coronavirus, and with added bullish/dovish momentum from the FOMC given downgrades to key components of the US economy and current inflation assessment. In terms of technical objectives, 174.78-80 beckons ahead of 174.92 and the next obvious round number target at 175.00, while the corresponding cash yield is now crossing -40 bp ahead of state and pan CPI, unemployment and Eurozone sentiment indicators before month end multi-tranche supply from Italy.

subject: CBRT Governor says 2020 year-end inflation forecast mid-point 8.2% (Prev. 8.2%), 2021 mid-point at 5.4%, inflation is expected to stabilise around 5% target in the mid-term, downward trend in inflation expected to continue throughout 2021
content:
• Inflation is expected to converge gradually to target, current stance is in-line with inflation targets, maintains prudential stance
  • Recovery in economic activity and labour market is expected to continue on the back of  disinflation process and improvement in financial condition
  • Does not expect aggregate demand to drive up inflation this year
  • Current dollarisation at 51% vs. 56% in May 2019, downward trend seen continuing
  • Do not have a TRY exchange rate target
reaction_details: • TRY has been weakening during early EU trade, albeit more-so on the overall weakness in the EM space as virus concerns weigh on the CNY

subject: Additional European Equities post release of the Daily European Equity Opening News
content:

content:

30th January 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian sentiment was downbeat as the overhang from the coronavirus outbreak continued to take its toll across the region and following an indecisive lead from the US, where markets reacted mixed to the FOMC which kept rates unchanged as expected. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.8%) were subdued with underperformance across Australian mining names as demand concerns overshadowed the higher quarterly production updates by Fortescue Metals and Newcrest Mining, but with downside for the broader market stemmed by resilience in financials, while losses in Tokyo were exacerbated by flows into the JPY. Elsewhere, KOSPI (-1.9%) was pressured after index heavyweight Samsung Electronics posted a 38% drop in Q4 net and Hang Seng (-2.2%) slipped deeper into correction territory after the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the mainland increased to 7711 and the death toll now at 170, while the TAIEX (-5.8%) slumped as Taiwan participants returned to the market for the 1st time in 10 days and took their turn to play catch up to the epidemic fears.

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 30th January 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • FOMC stood pat on rates as expected (raised IOER), whilst reiterating that the current policy stance is appropriate
  • China reported there are now 7711 total coronavirus cases and death toll at 170, while suspected cases are said to have increased to 12126
  • Asian sentiment was downbeat as the overhang from the coronavirus outbreak continued to take its toll across the region
  • UK PM Johnson will inform the EU he is prepared to accept post-Brexit border checks instead of Britain being under EU rules
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Unemployment Rate & CPI (Prelim), EZ Consumer Confidence, US GDP (Advance), Japanese CPI, Unemployment Rate & Retail Sales, BoE Rate Decision, MPR & Press Conference and supply from Italy
  • Earnings: Amazon, Visa, Verizon, Coca-Cola, UPS, Altria, Eli Lilly, Raytheon, Deutsche Bank, Roche

FOMC

FOMC left rates unchanged at 1.50%-1.75% as expected via unanimous decision and raised IOER by 5bps to 1.60%.

FOMC stated that the current policy stance is appropriate and downgraded its view on household spending activity to moderate pace from a strong pace. FOMC added that inflation returning to its target (prev. "near its target") and that it will continue monitoring incoming data, global developments and muted inflation.

Fed Chair Powell said some of the uncertainties around trade have diminished recently and other uncertainties remain such as the coronavirus, but global growth has stabilized. Furthermore, Powell stated Fed is not satisfied with inflation running below 2% which is not a ceiling and that the Fed will know when adjustments to the balance sheet have run course when reserves are durably at a sustainable level, while he suggested that reserves will not fall below September levels with USD 1.5tln level serving as a floor and that asset prices were “somewhat elevated”.

The reaction was mixed as T-Notes firmed slightly (10y yields down around 2bps), the DXY eased back to 98.00 and XAU added around USD 5 to USD 1575/oz. However, ES futures eventually saw some modest downside as there were concerns from some policymakers about the growing balance sheet and Powell noted that asset prices were “somewhat elevated” which would suggest that the Fed might not be so inclined to boost the balance sheet whilst they are "elevated” and may explain the negative ticks in ES. 

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China reported there are now 7711 total coronavirus cases and death toll at 170, while suspected cases are said to have increased to 12126. (Newswires) Note, the virus is now in every region of mainland China.

World Health Organization said evidence of human-to-human transmission outside of China is deeply concerning and suggested the numbers outside of China hold the potential for much larger outbreak, while it is to hold an emergency meeting today to re-evaluate whether the outbreak constitutes a Public Health Emergency of International Concern. (Newswires)

Japanese medical expert said it has been confirmed in China that the coronavirus can be transmitted from people without symptoms, while there were separate reports that 3 Japanese nationals who returned from Wuhan yesterday have tested positive for the coronavirus. (Newswires)

White House created a task force on coronavirus in which its members have been meeting daily since Monday, while US President Trump has charged the task force with leading the US government response to the coronavirus. (Newswires) White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said airlines are placing voluntary restrictions on flights to China due to virus outbreak and further restrictions are being discussed. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asian sentiment was downbeat as the overhang from the coronavirus outbreak continued to take its toll across the region and following an indecisive lead from the US, where markets reacted to the FOMC policy announcement. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.8%) were subdued with underperformance across Australian mining names as demand concerns overshadowed the higher quarterly production updates by Fortescue Metals and Newcrest Mining, but with downside for the broader market stemmed by resilience in financials, while losses in Tokyo were exacerbated by flows into the JPY. KOSPI (-1.9%) was pressured after index heavyweight Samsung Electronics posted a 38% drop in Q4 net and Hang Seng (-2.2%) slipped deeper into correction territory after the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the mainland increased to 7711 and the death toll now at 170, while the TAIEX (-5.8%) slumped as Taiwan participants returned to the market for the 1st time in 10 days and took their turn to play catch up to the epidemic fears. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher due to the broad weakness in risk appetite and following upside in T-notes which were supported post-FOMC and saw the US 10yr yield decline to a 3-month low, while the mostly improved results from the 2yr JGB auction added fuel to the upside momentum.

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson and Chancellor Javid wrote to cabinet ministers to demand savings ahead of the next Comprehensive Spending Review in the Autumn, while they are said to want hard commitments by March 2nd. (Sky News) The report suggests that cuts should be up to 5% of departmental budgets.

UK PM Johnson will inform the EU he is prepared to accept post-Brexit border checks instead of Britain being under EU rules which could mean additional paperwork and physical inspections of goods for businesses. (Telegraph)

UK Chancellor Javid will reportedly support the USD 88bln High Speed 2 rail scheme today in a decisive intervention which makes it almost certain the project will go ahead. (FT)

EU seeks to create a single European data market to challenge dominance of US tech giants, while large online platforms may face new rules to ensure open and fair competition according to an EU document. (Newswires)

UK Lloyds Business Barometer (Jan) 23 (Prev. 10). (Newswires) 

FX

DXY saw some mild pressure in reaction to the FOMC before steadying in Asia-Pac trade as it found a base around the 98.00 level and amid rangebound price action in its transatlantic counterparts. GBP/USD was unchanged ahead of today’s BoE coin-flip meeting and with EUR/USD stuck near 1.1000 where there are several hourly MA levels nearby and a EUR 1.2bln option expiry rolling off at today’s New York cut. USD/JPY trickled below 109.00 and JPY-crosses remained subdued on the broad risk-averse tone, which also resulted to declines in antipodeans despite further pushbacks to rate cut forecasts for both sides of the Tasman.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly lower owing to the broad risk averse tone seen during Asia trade which dragged WTI crude futures below the USD 53.00/bbl to extend on yesterday’s inventory-driven pressure after yesterday’s EIA report showed a larger than expected build in headline crude stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold was supported post-FOMC, although prices have since stalled and WGC also noted annual gold demand fell 1% last year, while copper underperformed as rising coronavirus cases plagues its largest purchaser China.

Algeria Energy Minster said it is very possible that the OPEC+ March meeting is advanced to February and that anything is possible when asked about extending the OPEC+ deal, according to state press. (Newswires)

OPEC is preparing a report on the coronavirus' impact on the oil market for members to review. (Newswires)

World Gold Council noted annual gold demand fell 1% Y/Y in 2019 to 4355.7 tons, while it expects India 2020 gold demand to rebound this year from a 3yr low in which it sees India gold demand at 700-800 tons vs. Prev. 690.4 tons last year but will remain below the 10yr average of 843 tons. (Newswires)

 

US 

Yields were lower across the curve by between 3.5 to 5.5bps, with the belly rallying. Major curve spreads, however, were mixed, with 2s5s, 2s10s, and 2s30s narrowing, while the 5s10s, 5s30sand 10s30s widened slightly. The Fed hiked the IOER but kept its main rate unchanged and extended its purchases through April (See Fed section for details). The complex saw upside as Powell noted that the Coronavirus had the capacity to weigh on China activity, while there were still uncertainties around trade policy. US T-notes (H0) settled 13 ticks higher at 131-00.

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the Fed has been moving in the right direction, but would like them to be bolder, while he also suggested that intensity of EU trade discussions will resume soon. (Fox Business News)

Coronavirus

China reported there are now 7711 total coronavirus cases and death toll at 170, while suspected cases are said to have increased to 12126. (Newswires)

Chinese government said it is to study and implement tax and financial support policies to mitigate effects of the coronavirus outbreak, while the China Ministry of Finance announced it has used fiscal subsidy of CNY 27.3bln to assist with virus control. (Newswires)

Chinese government economist said China Q1 growth could fall below 5% due to the virus with the forecast based on the assumption that the virus outbreak will peak by mid-February and end by March-end, while the impact from the coronavirus is seen as potentially significantly larger that the SARS outbreak from 2003. Furthermore, the economist added that Beijing is likely to step up policy support for the economy which could boost the budget deficit to over 3% of GDP this year, while the PBoC might further cut RRR and rates to provide support. (Newswires)

World Health Organization said evidence of human-to-human transmission outside of China is deeply concerning and suggested the numbers outside of China hold the potential for much larger outbreak. (Newswires)
